domain.name: AssemblyTask_domain
domain.documentation:
Version 1.0 by Pascal Bercher (pascal.bercher@uni-ulm.de, http://www.uni-ulm.de/en/in/ki/bercher)
The domain described here is the one used in the follwoing paper:
@Inproceedings { Bercher14HybridPlanningApplication, title = {Plan, Repair, Execute, Explain - How Planning Helps to Assemble your Home Theater}, year = {2014}, pages = {386--394}, abstract = {In various social, work-related, or educational contexts, an increasing demand for intelligent assistance systems can be observed. In this paper, we present a domain-independent approach that combines a number of planning and interaction components to realize advanced user assistance. Based on a components provide hybrid planning formalism, the facilities including the generation, execution, and repair as well as the presentation and explanation of plans. We demonstrate the feasibility of our approach by means of a system that aims to assist users in the assembly of their home theater. An empirical evaluation shows the benefit of such a supportive system, in particular for persons with a lack of domain expertise.}, url = {http://www.aaai.org/ocs/index.php/ICAPS/ICAPS14/paper/view/7901} publisher = {AAAI Press}, booktitle = {Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Automated Planning and Scheduling (ICAPS 2014)}, author = {Bercher, Pascal and Biundo, Susanne and Geier, Thomas and Hoernle, Thilo and Nothdurft, Florian and Richter, Felix and Schattenberg, Bernd} }
Note that our planning language does not support conditional effects. Several actions of the domain rely on that feature, however. We did compile these conditional effects away in a manual matter. This compilation incorporates the given problem instance. The action estTwoVideoFromAdapterToESystem is an example.
All cables, for instance, are devided into different sub sorts of sort Cable. These subsorts are never used by the actions, but they are used to create the initial state (manually), since some properties rely on the sub sort. For instance, to build (all) the correct groundings of PortIsCompatible(?port1,?port2), the respective cabe sub sorts were investigated. E.g., all SPDIF coaxial ports are compatible with all CINCH video ports.
It follows are short explanation how the domain model works w.r.t. the ports; note that the constants are given in the problem instance. A visualization of that problem is given by a PDF.
For every port of some sort (like the HDMI ports, sort: Port_HDMI), there are several port constants in the problem instance (p_HDMI_i, i in {1,...,n}). For the available devices, not all ports have been modeled, but only sufficiently many w.r.t. the available devices. For example, the A/V receiver (e_Amplifier) has only one HMDI output port (p_HDMI_3) and six HDMI input ports. For the input ports, only two have been modeled (using p_HDMI_1 and p_HDMI_2).
Note that there are *not* individual port constants for the different devices and cables. Instead, the port constants are used by several devices/cables. For instance, the constants p_HDMI_1 and p_HDMI_2 are used by all HDMI cables (one constant for one end) and also by the TV, the A/V receiver and the Blu-ray player. As a detailed example, consider one of the HDMI input ports of the A/V receiver. It is specified (in the problem) via: PortIsFemale(e_Amplifier,p_HDMI_1), PortIsSignalIn(e_Amplifier,p_HDMI_1), PortIsAudio(e_Amplifier,p_HDMI_1), PortIsVideo(e_Amplifier,p_HDMI_1).

sortDeclaration.name: Port
sortDeclaration.documentation: A port in which cables and/or adapters can be pluged in.

sortDeclaration.name: Device
sortDeclaration.documentation: Anything that has ports except cables.

sortDeclaration.name: EntertainmentSystem
sortDeclaration.documentation: Like a television, DVD player, etc.

sortDeclaration.name: SignalSource
sortDeclaration.documentation: Any Entertainment System that produces a signal

sortDeclaration.name: Adapter
sortDeclaration.documentation: Is used to convert different types of Ports.

sortDeclaration.name: Cable_Audio
sortDeclaration.documentation: All cables which can transport audion signals.

sortDeclaration.name: Cable_Video
sortDeclaration.documentation: All cables which can transport video signals.

sortDeclaration.name: Cable_Audio_and_Video
sortDeclaration.documentation: A cable for both video and audio.

relationDeclaration.name: hasAudioSignal
relationDeclaration.documentation: Specifies that the given SignalTransporter currently has an audio signal that was generated by the given EntertainmentSystem.

relationDeclaration.name: hasVideoSignal
relationDeclaration.documentation: Specifies that the given SignalTransporter currently has an audio signal that was produced by the specified EntertainmentSystem.

relationDeclaration.name: SignalTransporterIsBroken
relationDeclaration.documentation: Specifies that the given device does not work and should not be used.

relationDeclaration.name: PortIsUsed
relationDeclaration.documentation: Specifies that the port of the given device is already in use.

relationDeclaration.name: PortsAreCompatible
relationDeclaration.documentation: Specifies that the given ports are matching. Note that we do not distinct between input and output ports here: this is done by the actions using the PortIsSignalIn() and PortIsSignalOut() relations.

relationDeclaration.name: PortIsSignalIn
relationDeclaration.documentation: States that the given signal transporter has the specified port.

relationDeclaration.name: PortIsSignalOut
relationDeclaration.documentation: States that the given signal transporter has the specified port.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estOneVideoFromAdapterToESystem
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the adapter has one video signal, this action plugs it into an entertainment system (like a DVD player), s.t. this system also has that video signal.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estTwoVideoFromAdapterToESystem
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the adapter has two video signals, this action plugs it into an entertainment system (like a DVD player), s.t. this system also has both video signals. Note that this action uses problem instance-dependent information: the last two parameters are *all* the signal sources in the problem instance.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estOneVideoFromESystemToAdapter
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the entertainment system (like a DVD player) has a video signal, this action plugs an adapter into it s.t. this adapter also has that video signal.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estTwoVideoFromESystemToAdapter
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the entertainment system (like a DVD player) has both video signals, this action plugs an adapter into it s.t. this adapter also has both signals.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estVideoAndAudioFromDeviceToCable_A1V1_or_A2V2
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the device (like an adapter or a DVD player) has an audio and a video signal, this action plugs a cable into it s.t. the cable also has both signals.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estVideoAndAudioFromDeviceToCable_A1A2V1V2
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the device (like an adapter or a DVD player) has an audio and a video signal, this action plugs a cable into it s.t. the cable also has both signals.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estOneVideoFromDeviceToCable
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the device (like an adapter or a DVD player) has a video signal, this action plugs a cable into it s.t. the cable also has this signal.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estTwoVideoFromDeviceToCable
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the device (like an adapter or a DVD player) has both video signals, this action plugs a cable into it s.t. the cable also has both signals.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estOneVideoFromCableToDevice
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the cable has a video signal, this action plugs it into a device (like an adapter or a DVD player) s.t. the device also has this signal.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estTwoVideoFromCableToDevice
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the cable has both video signals, this action plugs it into a device (like an adapter or a DVD player) s.t. the device also has these signals.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estOneAudioFromCableToDevice
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the cable has an audio signal, this action plugs it into a device (like an adapter or a DVD player) s.t. the device also has this signal.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estTwoAudioFromCableToDevice
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the cable has both audio signals, this action plugs it into a device (like an adapter or a DVD player) s.t. the device also has these signals.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estVideoAndAudioFromCableToDevice_A1V1_or_A2V2
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the cable has an audio and a video signal, this action plugs it into a device (like an adapter or a DVD player) s.t. the device also has both signals.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estVideoAndAudioFromCableToDevice_A1A2V1V2
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the cable has an audio and a video signal, this action plugs it into a device (like an adapter or a DVD player) s.t. the device also has both signals.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estOneAudioFromDeviceToCable
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the device (like an adapter or a DVD player) has an audio signal, this action plugs a cable into it s.t. the cable also has this signal.

taskSchemaDeclaration.name: estTwoAudioFromDeviceToCable
taskSchemaDeclaration.documentation: Given the device (like an adapter or a DVD player) has both audio signals, this action plugs a cable into it s.t. the cable also has these signals.
